fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For a total category \mathcal {C}, we can define a functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) that will serve as the double left adjoint of \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} iff the category is actually a totally distributive category. Since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \hom (Y, X), we similarly define \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \operatorname {wave}(Y, X), and call the elements waves.

A wave w : Y \rightsquigarrow X is defined by a family of maps \hom (X, \operatorname {?} F) \to F(Y) natural in the presheaf F, where \operatorname {?} \dashv \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}. This is intuitively a categorification of the “way way below” relation Y \lll X in posets. If we take F = \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X), then we get an actual arrow \bar {w} : Y \to X. This defines a natural transform \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}, or equivalently \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id}.

We need to show that \operatorname {wave}(Y, X) is a small set. Let Y^* be the functor sending a presheaf F to the set F(Y). The right Kan extension is given by \begin {aligned} Y_* (A)(B) &= \hom (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (B), Y_* (A)) \\ &= \hom (Y^* (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (B)), A) \\ &= \hom (\hom (Y, B), A) = A^{B^Y}. \end {aligned} Using the fact that \mathsf {Set} is total and cototal and writing \operatorname {¿} as the witness of cototality, we calculate \begin {aligned} \operatorname {wave}(Y, X) &= \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?}, Y^*) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*, \textrm {Id}) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}} (\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (1^\textrm {op})) \\ &= \hom _{\mathsf {Set}} (1, \operatorname {¿}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } Y_*)) \\ &= \operatorname {¿}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} (X^\textrm {op}) \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } {Y_*}) \end {aligned} where the second equality is because the pseudofunctor (- \to \mathsf {Set}) preserves adjoint pairs. Hence we know this is a small set.
In a total category, we can freely compose waves with arrows or other waves associatively.

Let us use f, g, h etc. for arrows, and u, v, w for waves. The composition f \mathbin {\circ } w \mathbin {\circ } g and its associativity is given by functoriality of waves. We define the composition of two waves by w \mathbin {\circ } v = \bar {w} \mathbin {\circ } v = w \mathbin {\circ } \bar {v}, which we can verify are equal by a calculation. Then u \mathbin {\circ } v \mathbin {\circ } w = \bar {u} \mathbin {\circ } v \mathbin {\circ } \bar {w} is associative.

Given a total category \mathcal {C}, it is a totally distributive category, iff the wave functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \dashv \operatorname {?} with an obvious counit \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \to \textrm {Id}, and iff the natural transform \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id} is invertible (the inverse will be the unit of the adjunction). In this case, the composition operator \int ^B \operatorname {wave}(B, C) \times \operatorname {wave}(A, B) \to \operatorname {wave}(A, C) of waves is invertible, up to sliding B around with arrows.

Given a locally small category \mathcal {C}, if the Yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) has a left adjoint \operatorname {?}, then we say teh category is total, or totally cocomplete. This is equivalent to requiring the colimit of \pi _F : \int F \to \mathcal {C} to exist for every presheaf F, which is the value of L(F). Notice that \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} being fully faithful implies the counit \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) \to A is an isomorphism.

The universal property of the colimit says \hom (\operatorname *{colim} \pi _F, X) \cong \lim _{(Y, p)} \hom (Y, X). Using the characterization of limits in \mathsf {Set}, an element in this set maps F(Y) to \hom (Y, X) for each Y naturally, which is exactly \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).

Given a total category, if the left adjoint \operatorname {?} has a further left adjoint, then it preserves all limits. Since \operatorname {?} is a kind of colimit operator, this condition is a strong version of complete distributivity. Therefore we call the category totally distributive.
